name: Tartine Bakery's Tuna Tartine
description: If you've ever gotten the slightest bit interested in the art of making bread, chances are you've heard of Tartine, in San Francisco; they're widely known for making some of the best in the country. But the name Tartine is actually loosely translated as open-faced sandwich, and that's the sort of recipe featured in Edible Selby, a recently published compendium of photographer Todd Selby's whimsical columns regularly published in T: The New York Times Style Magazine.
recipeIngredient: 1 cup neutral oil, or a combination of neutral and olive
10-12 caperberries, roughly chopped (or an equivalent amount of capers)
10 ounces high-quality tuna in olive oil
Smoked paprika or za’atar, for dusting

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl, whisk together the yolk, mustard, and red wine vinegar with a good pinch of salt. While whisking vigorously, drizzle in the oil a little at a time to form the mayonnaise.
Stir the caperberries into the mayonnaise, then taste and season with salt and a splash of vinegar, if necessary.
Spread the caperberry mayonnaise onto the bread all the way to the edges. Spoon the tuna onto the bread and top it with a dusting of paprika.
Serve the open-faced sandwiches with a squeeze of lemon.
